captions.text: Hey there people.

Today we can do the quest to
answer all the supermarket
questions.
Stand by.
First things first.
Catify ze world!

I get asked the same questions
usually at the supermarket.

So today we're going to
knock out the first one.

Jackson, I'm trying to
introduce one cat to another,
and it ain't going well.

Today we're talking
about introductions.

Now let's get down
to the brass tacks.
How do we introduce cat to cat?

The first thing that folks
do wrong, is they go well,

I'm just going to bring my cat
into a room with this new cat
and let them work it out.

How many times have I
heard, let them work it out?

And how many times do
they not work it out?

What you want to do is introduce
these guys by scent first
and then work in sight.
It's all about cat mojo folks.

It's about
territorial ownership.

And if your cat, who has owned
this territory for x amount

of time, suddenly doesn't,
we're getting them off

on the wrong foot, because
you're putting it squarely
in the land of threat.

This cat is threatening
your cat's sanctified space.

The way that I introduce
cat to cat is I use a door.

I want to make sure that
on one side of the door,
it's usually a good base camp.

Base camp is a
room that's almost

like territorial
training wheels.
Right?

Well, first I'm going
to give you this room.

So you get to know what
the territory smells like.

And then we'll graduate
you out of here.

And I want you to
make sure that you're
practicing site swapping.

So what you want to
do, for instance,

is you've got the cat that's
out in the rest of the house.
Well, it's time to switch.
Put this one in the bathroom.
Bring the other one out.

Take the one from the
bathroom into the other room.

Now this whole thing will
take 3 and 1/2 minutes,

but I do want to make sure
that at any given time

the new cat or the resident cat
has a place to call their own.

Both a little bit
away and base camp.

The seat of the territory,
and the whole rest
of the territory.

On the other side
of that door, you

have your resident cat,
who has, for the most part,
free run of the house.

And you're going to
introduce them at meal times.

One on one side of the
door, one on the other.

If you are feeding
meals, you're gold, man.

Because your cat's
hungry, they're

going to want to
eat at that door.

they're motivated
to eat at that door.

And so they're going to
overcome the misgiving

they might have
with that other cat.

So that's really,
really crucial that you

keep feeding meals
and not free feeding.

Give them about three feet
on either side of that door.
Three feet from bowl to door.

Another three feet
from bowl to door.
Six feet total.

That way we're pretty
much respecting

the concept of personal space,
and a little bit of privacy.
And what are we doing?

We're setting up the concept
of positive association.
Right?

So that when these cats smell
food, they smell one another.
Now here's what I want from you.

When the two cats are eating
on either side of the door,
I want to see nothing.
No hissing.
No growling.
No shenanigans under the door.
No nothing.
OK.

Well if that's not happening,
then bring the bowls
apart a little bit more.

So what we're doing now,
as we've done in the past,
is setting a challenge line.

Saying you know,
where is it, Mr.

Cat that you find
enough confidence

that you can walk up to that
bowl, smell the other cat,

but smell your food,
eat it and walk away.

Wherever that is, that's
where we put a piece of tape

on the ground on either
side of that door.
Boom.

We got challenge
lines on either side,

and that first couple of
nights, walk up to the bowl,
eat, walk away, and onward.

Obviously, the next
thing you're going to do

is you're going to start moving
those bowls closer and closer
together.
We do this slowly.

Remember, a cat needs
to have it proven

to them that's this other
being is not a threat to them.

And the only way we can do
that is having the same result
over and over and over again.

Every time a bowl goes
down, I get my jackpot food.

I get no threat to the
environment, whatsoever.
I walk away.
You know, it's all good.

Another part of this
homework is graduate
from a closed door to the gate.

With the gate, you drape a
towel over the gate itself.

So now you've got a little bit
of visual space at the bottom.

So now these guys can
be eating their dinner

at their respective
challenge lines,

looking under there going,
wait a second, that's

a [NOM NOM NOM] that's
another [NOM NOM NOM].

It's like, I really want to
pay attention to that thing,
but it's really small, visually.
And this is really good food.

Now the next step is an exercise
that I call, Eat, Play, Love.

And the idea was you take two
cats that stand one another,

you put them in the same room,
but completely supervised.

And the idea is you want to
give them experience with toys.
What are their favorite toys?

How do you keep them
interacting with you,

and not paying any attention
to the other cat in the room?

Through play, then
through feeding a meal,

then through just
loving on them.

I just want them to
ignore one another.
That's the object of the game.

If it lasts for 15 seconds
before one cat's like,
huh, hey what the?
Who's that?

And then, all of
a sudden, game on.
Well that's fine.
That was 15 seconds.

Always end exercises
on a high note

to the best of your
ability, because we

don't want negative
associations to take root.

Every time these guys
get in a room together,
I want good things to happen.
They want good things to happen.

And if they do
continue to happen,

we will get to that point where
we'll be able to open the door
and let them at each other.

Everything that I just told you
about introducing cat to cat

works just as well when
your cats have had a fight,

and you're trying to get
them back together again.

So your homework for introducing
cat to cat, number 1,
start feeding meals only.
No free feeding.

Second, meal time
goes on opposite sides
of a closed door.

Every time you get
positive results,

stay with it for
a few days, folks.
Don't rush it.

It's on cat time,
not human time.

Then we get to the point
where we're right at the door.

A couple things you can
do, back it up again.

And now you can use the
baby gate type of deal.
Right?

You put the baby gate
down, put a blanket on top.

Slowly raising the curtain
on the proceedings,
and also bringing them together.

Again, repeating the same
technique you used before.

The other part of your
homework is Eat, Play, Love.

Concept here is expanding
out that meal time ritual.
Make sure you're site swapping.
Very, very important.

I don't want anyone
to get sort of static
in one location in the house.

I want it to be a
mix of locations

so that nobody can settle
into sort of false ownership.
And that's it.
Finally guys.

I'm telling you this from
the bottom of my heart.

I think cats should
be living groups.

I think that you should have
more than one cat in your life,
for sure.

But you've got to introduce
them on their terms.

All right folks, I'm
going to get going.

Now I have answered the
supermarket question
of the day.
More to come, believe me.

In the meantime, you can ask
your supermarket question.

You do not have to wait until
I'm holding a bag a celery
online at the Whole Foods.
No.

What you can do is #
TeamCatMojo, right here,
you see that.

And send it off on Twitter,
on Instagram, on Facebook.

And I will see those
questions and if I

get asked them enough
times, I will, for sure
answer those questions.

All right folks, until
next time, all light,
all love, all mojo to ya.

[KISSES] Love to you,
and your multiple cats.

title: The Best Way To Introduce Your Two Cats

comments.text:
I got a new cat last night (male) and I watched this video today and yes I 
thought that they would work it out tho they keep on hissing and what I'm 
asking is can I start this from today or I'd there no chance at all that it 
would work out﻿
comments.author: Y&F vloggers

comments.text: You are my hero! ﻿
comments.author: Amanda McKay

comments.text:
Help! I have followed Jacksons advice, we have 1 resident 2 year old 
Egyptian Mau, and we have just introduced a 6 month old Bengal to the 
house. The Bengal has been in her safe room for a week... and we are now at 
a stage where they will eat with bowls almost touching the door.. BUT, as 
soon as they catch sight of each either, (when I crack the door to see if 
its safe to go in, the resident cats fur stands on end and she growls and 
snorts. She just wants to kill the Bengal. I am also doing site swapping 
twice a day. Any thoughts on what to do now/next? I don't believe i can let 
them have supervised time together, the Mau has already tried to attack the 
kitten. Thank you.﻿
comments.author: tbadger

comments.text: What if it's 2 cats and a new kitten﻿
comments.author: pixierue Cicardo

comments.text:
I have been trying this video and one of my cats is not giving in. What 
else can I do.﻿
comments.author: MrJo0071

comments.text:
Not long ago we bought our second cat. Because my first male cat was fixed 
before puberty, he never had his territory and didn't really care about 
anything as long as he had food and some toys to play with.(he was a year 
and a half) When we brought a second male cat home (8months, also fixed 
before puberty) my first cat was really curious. I did locked them in 
different rooms and kept switching their toys so they can get used to each 
other's smell. My new cat was really scared of everything and always hid 
under things. In about two or three days he became more comfortable and I 
let my first cat out. At first they avoided each other but I started 
feeding them near each other and giving them yummy treats while they were 
near each other. Right now it's almost 5 months passed and its like they 
were born to be together. They play together and chase each other and just 
can't get enough. We got our second cat for free from another family 
because he was bullied by his cat parents and he was too playful and his 
cat parents weren't. I think that my first cat is really glad that he has a 
little brother now. They almost the same age so their level of playing is 
the same (but the little one is more playful) my first cat doesn't seem to 
mind at all. He also became less aggressive and doesn't scratch me at all 
when I pet him. They sometimes take a time off from seeing each other, my 
second cat likes to sleep under my bed when he feels bothered, it's like 
his little safety spot. He's not always there, just when he's nervous. They 
have two litter boxes and they both go in each of them. I live in a one 
bedroom apartment so it's only two rooms. My super cat highway is the top 
of my kitchen counters. They like to get there by jumping on a fridge and 
then jumping up. I have connected kitchen to the living room so they can 
see everything from up there. Love them both to death. Thank you so much 
for all of your tips and help. I raised my first cat from his kitten age 
and raised him on watching your show. Both of them are so spoiled now they 
have their own toy box and different tubes in which they can hide all 
around the apartment. Thank you for everything <3
﻿
comments.author: Katya_cat

comments.text: yep....my cat and I are just havin some chillin time on the couch﻿

comments.text: Excellent video...many good points here.﻿

comments.text:
I have two cats, and my roommate has a cat. I tried to introduce the cats: 
feeding them next to the door (my roommate would not change his cat's 
feeding habit of free-feeding his cat), swapping them out to let them sniff 
where the others had been, and everything was going well until I used the 
gate - it all went to hell and never improved despite my efforts. 
It's been 2 years, his cat stays in his room and goes nowhere else, we have 
to keep his door shut, if the cats ever see each other the claws a teeth 
come out, and his cat now pees on all of his stuff constantly.
What should I do? =(﻿

comments.text: Thank you Jackson, you are amazing!﻿
comments.author: blingeefairy

comments.text:
Can anyone out there help in my citation: I was given a sickly kitten who 
needed round the clock care. I wasn't able to section him off in a room. My 
cat of 6 years currently hates the kitten (who is doing much better) The 
overactive kitten will jump on the cat or chase him. The cat has taken to 
growling whenever the kitten walks by. I have started timeouts for the 
kitten to stop the fight and get some peace, but I'm sure this is wrong. 
How do I get the cat to stop acting like prey, growling at the kitten and 
how do I get the kitten to stop attacking the cat (though I think he is 
just playing). Also are they fighting when I'm not home? They always look 
like they were napping, but I'm not sure. ﻿
comments.author: MissThiaT

comments.text:
+MissThiaT try separating them when you are not home. I had a two year old 
male cat and we had just gotten a girl kitten last year. she was 3 months 
when me and my bf got her. The kitten would always want to play with the 
male cat, and then male cat would hiss at the kitten, bite her on the neck, 
and sometimes drag her around like a piece of meat. it used to scare the 
crap out of me i thought he was going to kill her which is why i would 
separate them when someone wasnt home. i am sure your adult cat just needs 
to assert his dominance, because it only took about three months for the 
biting to fully stop and now the two cats love each other.
comments.author: Alexandria Lamti

comments.text:
I wnana try meal time, but I dont know how much or how many times a day I 
should do it.﻿
comments.author: Lori Vasconcellos

comments.text:
I found this quite interesting though I have to admit it seems like an 
awful lot of work that I'm not certain is really necessary. We've had cats 
my entire life (50 plus now) and the standard cat introduction system was 
simply putting the latest down in the house and supervising for the first 
hour or so to make certain nothing untowards happens. Though there's been 
growling and hissing at times in the beginning, it dies down in a day or so 
and there's never been attacks or fights.
Our latest set includes a 13 year old who was adopted with his brother (now 
passed) as a ten year old, an eight year old who was adopted as a five year 
old a week after the 13 year old, and two two year olds who were adopted as 
kittens.﻿
comments.author: Rhonnda Oliver

comments.text:
My home has no interior doors except for the bathroom, which is Small. What 
is the best way to introduce? I've done #1, smell of each other. I've had a 
Russian Blue mix, spayed female for 2 1/2 years. She is also a rescue and 
has lived with us since she was 8 weeks old. Our new kitty, Smokey, is a 2 
year old nuetered male who has lived his entire life in a shelter. He is a 
gentle boy, doesn't hiss or growl at Cutie. Last night, she actually showed 
submission to him by flopping on her tummy. She was hiding but isn't as 
much today, is staying in the same room, growling only a bit softly. She 
only hisses when he comes too close. Does what I've done sound like it's 
working?﻿
comments.author: Stephanie Ward

comments.text:
Bollocks.  These cats are getting their shit together today.  TODAY.  No

cat goes in room. sort your shit out.  You living together. No freaking

comments.author: Barry Neilson

comments.text:
Hi Jackson. My friend and I just moved into a house with 2 cats and a small 
dog. Her female dog and male cat are adjusting well and hanging out in the 
entire house. My female cat won't leave my bedroom and is hissing and 
growling when she sees/hears the other animals. We watched this video and 
put a plan in motion to reintroduce them with food. We just started so we 
haven't seen a lot of progress yet but I am confident. I was wondering if 
you had any pointers specific to our situation. My female cat is also over 
grooming and has a bald stomach and hind legs. She was in a shelter 4 
months ago and she has been on preganozone to help with her over grooming 
since before we moved in but I noticed she is doing it even more now. I 
know that it can take a lot of time for cats to adjust to new situations 
but it's hard seeing her so stressed out.﻿
comments.author: Nicole Taylor

comments.text: What about cat to dog/puppy?﻿
comments.author: AishaSaysDance!

comments.text: Flipping hell. What an egg head﻿
comments.author: Naomi “NaomiVlogs” Booton

comments.text:
Hi I'm have a New 3months old Persian but this is my first time that I have 
persisn inside my house. But the problem is, he poops 5times in 1day is 
that okay ? Or not? And How often bath the 3months old kitten? Is it, once 
or twice a week?﻿
comments.author: Laarni Dungca

comments.text:
+Laarni Dungca
( I'm thinking out loud here, so don't mind me ! ! ! ).

Persian kitties are known for their long fur. 

If you allow your precious feline friends outside, this could mean that his 
or her fur will get dirty, no doubt. 

With that said, giving your kitty a bath at least twice a month, should 
not be a problem. 

I had an aunt who had a Persian kitty named Lucy.  

Lucy was white and although my aunt allowed to roam outside, I don't think 
that Lucy's fur got dirty.  

My aunt STILL gave her a bath, anyways.   

Not everyday, just occasionally.  

Lucy was a spoiled kitty, as she would not jump up on the dining room table 
nor did she eat anything you offered her from the table. 

( If you had leftover food in your plate and you offered it to her, she 
would walk away from it ).  

She would only eat her cat food ! ! ! 

Sadly, Lucy got sick, ( her fur started to fall out ), and my aunt had to 
give her to the shelter.
comments.author: ms. will always love my life

comments.text:
Actually I Bought this kitten persian when he was 3mos. Then the owner of 
kitten or persian cat , she said that I will do twice a month to bath our 
kitten. Is that right?
comments.author: Laarni Dungca

comments.text:
+Laarni Dungca 
You should not have to bathe your precious kitty at all, as cats usually 
groom themselves.  

( I thought everyone knew this ).  

However, if kitties' fur is dirty or he / she may have fleas or ticks, then 
a bathe certainly would be needed.   

But as far as your kitty, um, " pooping " more than five times for the day, 
it could be 'cause of one of the following:

( 1 )   It could be that the cat food you are feeding him / her is not 
agreeing with his / her stomach

( 2 )   Your kitty is just getting used to his / her environment, which is 
probably causing him / her an upset stomach 

You could try a different brand of cat food or better yet, take your 
precious feline friend to the vet.    

Of course, the above statement was just my opinion.  

I am not a vet.
comments.author: ms. will always love my life

comments.text: A firm beating usually keep my two cats from fighting.﻿

comments.author: Queen Fatimah

comments.text:
Thank you Jackson! I've owned a stray black kittie (indoors only and under 
a vet's care) for the last 2 years and things are going very well... I'm 
thinking about adopting another homeless black kittie for her company while 
I'm at work as I (we) are already setup and we are cat friendly. My single 
kittie is used to being #1 and I'm worried about the impact of bringing in 
a second kittie yet all my friends and family have two kitties, not one.... 
I'd hate to adopt and then return a black kittie to a kill shelter - I just 
can't do it. I will keep ya posted. Your program has been very beneficial 
in helping me (us) understanding my kittie's (and human's) behavior. We 
both thank and love you. Either way, we will be watching your videos and 
programs closely. Ultimately - yes I agree and as you said - "Cats should 
live and thrive in groups" (not alone)- very well said.﻿

comments.text: great videos - keep them coming ﻿

comments.text:
The introduction between my 2 cats was kinda working but it looks like it's 
gonna have to be given a 2nd shot. We moved into a new home aswell, they 
have been so brave. We have feliway, there own toys etc. But they are still 
competitive with each other. We separate them when it gets a bit nasty, one 
is curious and the other want to be left alone but the curious one has 
learnt early on not to bother the other too much, I make up the play time 
with her. It's a hard road. ﻿
comments.author: lady_luck

comments.text:
Jackson, the two-cat dynamic going on in my home has a slight variation to 
the standard version you are addressing in vid. I have 2 neutered males, 
6-7 yrs. One of my cats (I'll call him Cat A) had to go to the vet recently 
(UT crystals, which I caught right away), and since keeping them separated 
while he recoups, the other one (Cat B) has become circumspect of him, and 
they can't seem to be reintroduced without a bloodbath! They were never 
lovey-dovey to begin with, but they, at least, had an acceptance of the 
other and have always spent most of their time in the same room hanging 
out... until now. Additionally, the day I had to take Cat A to the vet, my 
first attempt at getting him in the carrier was a colossal FAIL, and Cat B 
was so agitated by the commotion, hissing and protests of Cat A that he was 
compelled to beat the F--- out of Cat A! Energy escalating energy! Poor Cat 
A was already weakened by feeling sick, only to wind up getting blood and 
fur drawn! It was as if they had established some sort of new dynamic of 
searing hate towards each other, of which, I can't seem to reset!
Should I treat them like two strangers now - introducing them for the first 
time? Or, considering that they have known each other for years, is there 
another method or technique that would work more specifically? These cats 
live here year-round with my 80 yr old mother, while I am here only for the 
winter months. When I leave town, they will remain with her, and I can't 
afford to have her managing a nightmare at her age, by herself! Thank you 
so much, Jackson! Blessings to you always...
PS. I am also a musician - like you!﻿
comments.author: Donya Lane

comments.text:
+Kay Baggett Thank you for sharing and suggestions. I did work it out, 
mostly by doing EVERYTHING that Jackson explains in this video. The only 
variation was that I never used a gate. I used door stops and just started 
jamming the door opened by a few inches when they were eating. It took 
about a week of patience and being as inventive and creative as necessary. 
The point you made about your cat preventing the other from using the 
box... wow, that's horrible! I have not observed that going on here, but I 
will keep an eye out. I also added an extra box to the house, which helps.
comments.author: Donya Lane

comments.text:
+Donya Lane I think that B has probably been keeping A from the litter box 
and so he's holding his urine and that can cause crystals. Also B has 
probably been keeping A from the water bowl and that can cause crystals. I 
had the same issue and didn't realize it till my female cat had to have 
major surgery. If you can keep B shut up when getting A into the kennel and 
if you can keep B away from A to allow A to heal it will be good. There 
must be fresh water every day and in several places to help A get well and 
keep the crystals from coming back. Also cats sense when another is weak 
and sometimes they want to take advantage of that. So B is bullying A 
because A is sick. Feel badly for your mother.
comments.author: Kay Baggett

comments.text:
PS. I just realized that you probably answered my question already @ 5:52. 
Thank you for all these methods. I guess this means we are starting over 
from the very beginning in this house... Peace is the goal (for cats AND 
humans!).

comments.text:
Hello If anyone out there has any advice I'd GREATLY appreciate it:
I had two cats and I found a third cat in the streets. It was getting cold 
out and I couldn't bring myself to ignore the cat so I took it home and put 
up signs. I then took the cat to the vet to make sure it was healthy. I've 
grown attached to the cat and after trying to rehome it myself I couldn't 
bring myself to put him in a shelter. My two cats seem unhappy about the 
situation and whenever one seems to be having progress the other ends up 
freaking them out. I have tried the introduction process but they have not 
responded at the same rate. Introducing them to each other was a LOT less 
stressful.
If anyone has any tips for introducing multiple cats I'd VERY MUCH 
appreciate it. I feel like I'm running out of options and it would break my 
hear to have to give the stray up to a shelter. Please note we live in a 
VERY small space and do not have multiple rooms. I know the situation is 
far from ideal but I cant bring myself to just give up on them.﻿
comments.author: Ann Raggedy

comments.text:
Get yourself a very large dog cage, that is what we did when introducing 
our kittens to our cats, and we placed the kittens in the cage, now, you 
need to watch the cage since the cats can climb out, they can sniff and see 
each other through the cage without hurting each other, put food and toys 
in the cage, and play with both cats in the cage and out

comments.author: sleeksheepfox

comments.text:
Repost from the instagram account:

" Hello friends and @thecatdaddy. http://instagram.com/p/rA_o6jrx5P/ 
They're my feline family the calico is Maggie she's six. The white and 
black is Maya she's almost 3. Muriel the black one and our little Sam. 
They're all rescued from the streets. They live also with 2 rescued 
poodles. They all get along. Except Maya she doesn't trust the others and 
her insecurity is causing the others to attack her :(... advices? Meal time 
is not a problem as you noticed﻿
comments.author: Azaria Abarca

comments.text:
I would take Maya to the vet for a full check up.  Often, when one animal 
has a health issue the others will stalk and sometimes attack.

If no health issues, do a reintroduction following the techniques in 
Jackson's video.  It is possible that the integration of Maya was done too 
quickly for her.  If all that does not help, I would have her in another 
room shut off from the other cats when you are sleeping or not home, so she 
can have lots of peaceful, stress free time.  You might also try to find 
her a new home as an only cat, or in a home with just one other cat that 
has a mellow temperament, and where you instruct the new  owners on doing a 
very slow introduction.

In addition, when you feed them, don't have them all bunched up together.  
That leads to many cats eating too quickly for fear the others will nudge 
in to get the other's food. Eating too fast can wind up causing stomach 
upset and regurgitation/vomiting.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

comments.text:
You can give everyone a dose of Rescue Remedy (up to 5 drops per day per 
cat or kitten) to take the edge off.  It will make Maya less fearful and 
the others less aggressive.  Watch for any aggression aimed toward Maya - 
heavy staring, stalking, growling, hissing, or chasing -- and give the 
aggressor a 10 minute timeout in  a carrier or the bathroom.  Then be sure 
to redirect aggression toward toys to play-out those predatorial energies 
before Maya can be victimized again.  Kitty fishing poles or laser mice 
generally work best as prey substitutes.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
Muitas pessoas tem um gato e deseja #adotar outro. Veja como apresentar um

comments.author: Babá de Animais

comments.text:
My old cat is fortunately taking in my new kitten fine.. I did let the 
kitten stay in the transporter for 10 minutes before I put her into the 
bathroom where the litterbox is so she knew where that was. I have always 
free fed dry food, but the cat's only get canned food in the morning and in 
the evening and the kitten get her milk morning and evening too. My older 
cat was hissing a bit at first when the kitten came too near or was too 
naughty, but now they are playing and having fun together.. I also have a 
dog and the kitten is already used to dogs so that went well, actually the 
dog is a bit jealous of the attention the cats get xD  ﻿

comments.text:
Hi, I made the mistake by not doing any research on introducing two cats 
when i brought my newly adopted kitten home yesterday.  My older cat won't 
leave her alone, and since they've already associated negative aggression 
with each other, what can I do to help improve their relationship? Should I 
just follow this video even though they have already seen each other and 
constantly fight/bother each other?﻿
comments.author: Lisa Le

comments.text:
Yes, if they are fighting, separate and start over.  Contact the rescue to 
let them know you are having trouble.   If your older cat has never lived 
with another cat, then do not leave her with the kitten unsupervised.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
I did this when I got my cat because my Maltese dog was terrified of him (I 
know, weird). Now they're best friends :)﻿
comments.author: Amalia Lopez

comments.text: Does this work with with introducing a dog to cat?Or dog to cats?﻿
comments.author: Momoosse

comments.text:
Similarly, you should start the cat in a separate space, after making sure 
the cat is ok with dogs AND that your dog is not feline-aggressive.   You 
do the second part by visiting cat-owning friends with your pup on lead 
inside the house, ensuring no chase can take place.   Then, you review all 
basic obedience commands to get your dog to ignore the cat and focus on 
you.    Then you practice quiet, calm behavior while standing on your dog's 
leash.   If the dog can leave off trying to chase the cat, it bodes well 
for co-habitation.  You go through similar steps when you bring your 
dog-friendly cat home -- after the cat has acclimated in their starter 
space.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
